ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned how motor controllers work, PID controls, how to interpret motor and software datasheets, etc. Basically all the under the hood things that go into making a robot.
Great class taught me about coding arduino registers, how microcontrollers work, Intro to laplace transforms, control methods, PID controllers. Very good class

Learned about control theory, computers, measurements devices, wave form generators, PIDs, and robotics. Learned how to read datasheets and try unique solutions to problems as the course was relatively open ended.

A good in-depth perspective of robotics and systems with response, feedback, and the like. The labs were cool to get hands-on experience, and in coding the final project you gain the skills of tuning controllers, understanding code and systems, and putting theories in practice.
This course gave a great introduction to the theory and application of basic robotics principles.
I learned how to code in arduino and translate between the electronics and mechanical aspects for a robot.
Basics of control theory.
I learned about PID controllers and various aspects of robotics.
I learned about mechatronics, but I would not say that it was in great detail. My understanding was not amazing after leaving the course.
We learned about various aspects of control systems and how to control robotic dynamic systems.

Learned how mechatronic systems worked, learned how programming works at most basic level, how signals are sent and received on a computer system, how to describe these systems with math and implement them in hands-on way in labs
I learned how electrical systems and computers work, as well as how to control mechanical systems with electronics.

By the end of the course, I understood why control theory exists, and felt ready to tackle another course that actually focuses on how to control systems. In the meantime, I picked up some knowledge and practical skills relating to simple robotics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Especially near the beginning, I left class wanting more motivation for why we were learning what we were and what it went towards. There was a haze of scanning datasheets blindly, so maybe some restructuring of the material order or adding more blips of foresight about what things we'd eventually do.
The class is supper entertaining but the prof moves very fast and assumes a strong math foundation as for there's lots to cover in the class

Lectures went really fast without much detail which made the homework challenging. The labs were well written and where I received most of the learning. Ian is a really nice professor who cares about learning and offers ample opportunities to receive help.

I think some of the labs could have been more neatly organized, and perhaps more focused on the finals project. The classes were sometimes difficult to understand, but Ian was great at helping students get a good grasp of it and not waste their time on pointless things.
This course had some really good labs, that directly reinforced what we'd been talking about in class.
It was geared toward someone who knows how to code. I dont know how, so it was tough to jump into on day 1. Professor Abraham was very good at breaking down what was under the hood.

Strengths: the prof is very responsive, flexible and really open to explaining confusing concepts. Homeworks, labs exams and projects were very straightforward. 

Weaknesses: overall structure was kind of confusing. At one point, I am pretty sure 95% of the students had absolutely no idea what was going on in class. Might be just the material, I don't know.

This course was run amazingly. The labs were focused in on the content, and the homeworks were fit for student learning. Recorded lectures may help the class to allow students to review material again.
The material is interesting. However, it was not presented in an understandable fashion. The assignments did not really help in learning as well.

I think the professor is what made the course as engaging as it was. Lectures sometimes felt a little too fast and like too much information all at once, but he was always willing to answer any questions and he always asked for feedback on the way he structured labs and other assignments. He just made the material interesting even if it was too abstract to understand at times. We also didn't have a lot of psets and we had 2 weeks for lab reports (5 labs) so the workload wasn't bad at all. Labs were a little difficult sometimes too, but interesting and fun as well!

Strengths: well-organized, interesting final project, succinct lectures. Weaknesses: sometimes the context of specific material wasn't given before/during lecture and it made it really hard to follow, some of the labs were really long and I didn't understand them  very well
It is a fun course and the labs were great. I wish there was more builds in the labs.

I was initially skeptical about how all the different parts would come together to an understanding of how engineers design robots, but it ultimately did and I was pleased. Honestly cannot think of any big weaknesses of the course. Some small ones, maybe, such as I never quite got the time to understand how root locus plots translate to motion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Likely it's a major requirement, so you have to take it. The project at the end is cool!
Do yourself a favor and take this class! it was a pleasure to be lectured by prof. Ian. The content is super engaging and insightful as to how mechatronic systems work!

This was a fun class to learn robotics. I would recommend to ME, EE, and CS majors interested in control systems. It was not that challenging and the workload was low but some problem sets got very difficult (though there were only five all semester). It is a cool elective and also ABET requiremnt

To any mechanical engineering major (and even EE / EECS) this course should be a priority. It is a really cool way to use what you've learned in other classes and get to play with robots. There is a bit of coding, and some maths so definitely take those prereqs, but I would highly recommend taking this course before graduating, and even before doing capstones if your capstone will involve robotics / Arduino / coding.
Yes! I loved this class and found it very rewarding. If you have any interest in programming arduinos, take it.
I would recommend this course to any engineers - the topic is so important to the world today, and the class is really well structured.
Yes! It helps if you have good background on Arduino and some EENG topics. Also comfort with Laplace transforms, Fourier series
Best class at Yale in engineering so far
I would if someone really wanted to learn something useful at Yale
Sure, Id say so.
I would highly recommend this class to any mechanical engineering major. You get to apply engineering skills while still learning the theory behind it.
Yes, I think once Prof Abraham teaches it again it will be a lot better as he knows which parts work well.
Yes! It's a MENG requirement, but it ended up being one of my favorite classes!
Yes I would, good balance of theory and hands-on, Professor Abraham is great
Yes, it is a great course and I learned a lot about electronic systems.

Yes, even to those for whom ABET doesn't require it. I definitely feel much more aware of the connections between code and movement. I think it would be even better to take this course followed by another robotics course such as the 400-level elective that Ian is planning to teach.
